channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Why Portland, Among the Whitest U.S. Cities, Embraced Black Lives Matter
item.description: In a state with a brutal racist history, the Black Lives Matter protests in Portland, Ore., have been overwhelmingly attended by white demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Octavio Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters gathered to listen to Black Lives Matter activists in Portland, Ore., on Thursday.

item.title: Feds Sending Tactical Team to Seattle, Expanding Presence Beyond Portland
item.description: After outrage over the presence of federal agents in Portland, Ore., the Trump administration is sending a team to Seattle. Officials say they will be on standby.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Adam Goldman and Mike Baker
item.media:description: Mayor Jenny Durkan of Seattle last week. She said on Thursday that she did not want federal agents deployed to the city.

item.title: “Immigration Nation” Drew Complaints From ICE, Filmmakers Say
item.description: A new documentary peers inside the secretive world of immigration enforcement. The filmmakers faced demands to delete scenes and delay broadcast until after the election.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Dickerson

item.title: ‘It’s Emotional Whiplash’: California Is Once Again at the Center of the Virus Crisis
item.description: The state was the first to issue a stay-at-home order, helping to control an early outbreak. It has now surpassed New York for the most known cases of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: People visited Venice Beach in Los Angeles on Wednesday. The city has seen the most cases in California, and while parts of it feel under siege, in other areas there is little palpable sense of the severity of the situation.

item.title: The F.B.I. Pledged to Keep a Source Anonymous. Trump Allies Aided His Unmasking.
item.description: After a Russia expert who had collected research on Donald Trump for a disputed dossier agreed to tell the F.B.I. what he knew about it, law enforcement officials declassified a road map to identifying him.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: The Justice Department has said that Attorney General William P. Barr determined that declassifying a report about F.B.I. interview was in the public interest.

item.title: Judge Rejects Challenge to Federal Agents Targeting Portland Protesters
item.description: Oregon’s attorney general had sued to prevent federal agents from patrolling the city in unmarked vehicles and detaining protesters.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Photo by Caitlin Ochs/Reuters, Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The C.D.C.’s package on school reopenings included mixed messages.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: Rene Carpenter, Astronaut’s Wife Who Broke NASA Mold, Dies at 92
item.description: The last living member of the Mercury 7 couples who helped define America’s early space program, she went on to become a writer and television host.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:credit: Ralph Morse/The LIFE Picture Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Rene Carpenter watching the launch of her husband, Scott Carpenter, aboard the Aurora 7 capsule in 1962. She declined to conform to the expectations of astronauts’ wives.

item.title: U.S. Warns Russia, China and Iran Are Trying to Interfere in the Election. Democrats Say It’s Far Worse.
item.description: The government statement was short on details, reminiscent of the vague warnings in 2016 that, in retrospect, failed to seize the attention of officials and voters before the last presidential election.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:credit: Erik Branch for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling station last month during the primary in Louisville, Ky.

item.title: As He Woos Drugmakers on Virus, Trump Demands Drug Price Controls
item.description: President Trump is trying to revive a 2016 campaign promise to control the rising price of medicines, but new executive orders are coming when he needs drugmakers to deliver coronavirus treatments.
item.dc:creator: Margot Sanger-Katz, Noah Weiland and Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump signing one of multiple executive orders on Friday meant to lower prescription drug prices for consumers.

item.title: Kimberly Guilfoyle’s Fund-Raising for Trump Draws Scrutiny
item.description: Ms. Guilfoyle has raised money from donors and has made inroads with some who have rejected calls from others. Yet Trump supporters inside and outside the campaign say the operation she’s built hasn’t lived up to expectations.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Kimberly Guilfoyle and Donald Trump Jr. arriving at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland after traveling with President Trump.

item.title: Robert E. Lee High in Virginia Will Be Renamed for John Lewis, District Says
item.description: Mr. Lewis, the civil rights giant who died last week, beat out a list that included Barack Obama and Cesar Chavez to have the high school, in Fairfax County, named after him.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Levin Corbin Handy/Library of Congress, Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students said they wanted their school, currently named for the Confederate general Robert E. Lee, to honor someone they could aspire to. In September, it will become John R. Lewis High School.

item.title: When Caring for Your Child’s Needs Becomes a Job All Its Own
item.description: For some parents, work outside the home is impossible as they navigate complicated and frustrating systems for help. But they don’t have to go it alone.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Stewart

item.title: C.D.C. Calls On Schools to Reopen, Downplaying Coronavirus Risks
item.description: The agency’s statement followed earlier criticism from President Trump that its guidelines for reopening were too “tough.”
item.dc:creator: Abby Goodnough
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration
item.media:description: A teacher collected personal belongings and supplies needed to continue remote teaching through the end of the school year in June at an elementary school in New York.

item.title: Bruce Blair, Crusader for Nuclear Arms Control, Dies at 72
item.description: A former Minuteman launch officer, he sounded alarms about how easy it is to start a nuclear attack, and about the lack of safeguards.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Safe to Go Out? Republicans and Democrats Widely Split
item.description: A survey shows that the partisan divide on the coronavirus goes beyond masks. It extends to dining out, getting on a plane and resuming other activities.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A San Antonio movie theater reopened in May after Texas lifted lockdown orders. A survey found a wide partisan split on readiness to resume dining out, going to theaters or flying.

item.title: Videos Show How Federal Officers Escalated Violence in Portland
item.description: Peaceful protests were already happening for weeks when federal officers arrived on July 4. Our video shows how President Trump’s deployment ignited chaos.
item.dc:creator: Ainara Tiefenthäler, Evan Hill, Drew Jordan, Malachy Browne and David Botti
item.media:credit: Photo by Caitlin Ochs/Reuters, Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: Three Storms Churn Across the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans
item.description: Douglas, in the Pacific Ocean, remained a Category 3 hurricane while Hanna was expected to make landfall in Texas as a Category 1 storm, forecasters said. Tropical Storm Gonzalo had weakened.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Courtney Sacco/Corpus Christi Caller-Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: City employees in Corpus Christi, Texas, handed out sandbags on Friday. Tropical Storm Hanna is expected to make landfall in the Gulf Coast of Texas on Saturday.

item.title: Marlene Sekaquaptewa, Hopi Tribal Leader and Quiltmaker, Dies at 79
item.description: She played a major role in Hopi Tribal government for decades while raising a large family. She was governor of the village of Bacavi when she died after testing positive for Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero

item.title: Nadine Taub, Early Leader in Women’s Rights Law, Dies at 77
item.description: Along with other feminist lawyers like Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Ms. Taub made legal history in cases that argued that the Constitution protected women’s rights.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: Covid Pandemic and Recession Hurt Nonprofits as Need Surges
item.description: Even as the economic crisis creates new demand for their services, organizations with millions of workers are resorting to layoffs as revenues dry up.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kulish
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Sebastian Hidalgo for The New York Times
item.media:description: After being furloughed from her contracting assignment, Melody Boykin turned to the Y.M.C.A. in Chicago for food and supplies for her and her 2-year-old son.

item.title: Trump Administration Is Bypassing Arms Control Pact to Sell Large Armed Drones
item.description: The move has been opposed internally by arms control officials and lawmakers trying to limit the proliferation of such drones, especially in countries like Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: An American Reaper drone this month at Amari Air Base in Estonia.

item.title: Fact Checking Trump's Claims on Election Battlegrounds
item.description: From lobsters in Maine to ethanol in Iowa to the oil fields of Texas, the president has tried to bolster his case for re-election by promoting localized — and factually challenged — accomplishments.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:description: President Trump on Wednesday at the White House.

item.title: FEMA Sends Faulty Protective Gear to Nursing Homes Battling Virus
item.description: The controversy over inadequate protective equipment has come to embody what critics describe as a haphazard federal effort to protect the 1.5 million Americans who live in nursing homes.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence helped deliver a shipment of personal protective equipment provided by FEMA to the Woodbine Rehabilitation and Healthcare Center in Alexandria, Va., in May.

item.title: Making the Most of a Pandemic Staycation
item.description: Families who stayed put in cities during the pandemic are rediscovering new ways to appreciate their neighborhoods and even their homes.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Trump Presses Limits on Transgender Rights Over Supreme Court Ruling
item.description: The Trump administration is pressing forward with policies limiting transgender rights. Many rules that have been in development for years have now either been finalized or have gone into effect.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:description: The Trump administration policy is a small piece of a broader, government-wide effort to diminish protections for transgender people.

item.title: Gold vs. Salmon: An Alaska Mine Project Just Got a Boost
item.description: The Trump Administration, rejecting concerns over the risks to Alaska’s fishery, cleared the way on Friday for the Pebble Mine.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain and Acacia Johnson
item.media:description: A work camp on the tundra near the site of the proposed Pebble Mine in Southwest Alaska.

item.title: How Covid-19 Made it Easier to Talk About Climate Change
item.description: Climate policy director Rhiana Gunn-Wright, architect of the Green New Deal, explains the connections between the pandemic and the climate crisis.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Michael Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rhiana Gunn-Wright at the DealBook/DC Strategy Forum in Washington last year.

item.title: Christopher Columbus Statues Removed From 2 Chicago Parks
item.description: Crews removed statues of the explorer from Grant Park and Arrigo Park early on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Tyler Lariviere/Sun-Times/Chicago Sun-Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Crews removed the Christopher Columbus statue from Grant Park early Friday morning.

item.title: When Can Schools Reopen Safely in California?
item.description: Friday: A professor of epidemiology at U.C. Davis talks about what is necessary to safely reopen schools. Also: Tesla’s surprise profit sets it up for another major milestone.
item.dc:creator: Marie Tae McDermott
item.media:description: The cafeteria area of a closed elementary school in Los Angeles.

item.title: Requiem for a Republican Convention
item.description: President Trump’s decision to cancel the Jacksonville convention underscores how the coronavirus has upended the presidential race. This afternoon, he signed several executive orders addressing the high price of drugs in the United States.
item.media:description: President Trump arriving at his coronavirus news briefing on Thursday where he announced the cancellation of the Florida portion of the Republican National Convention.

item.title: Trump Wants Schools to Reopen. Americans Worry It’ll Happen Too Fast.
item.description: The president is insisting that schools reopen in the fall, but polls show that Americans are gravely concerned about the prospect, setting up the issue as a key question for November.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:description: St. Benedict School in Montebello, Calif., placed social distancing dividers in a classroom. Across the country, educators have confronted a politically charged debate over reopening schools.

item.title: A More Accessible World
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Meet the Brave but Overlooked Women of Color Who Fought for the Vote
item.description: In “Finish the Fight!,” excerpted here, New York Times journalists tell the stories of lesser-known figures in the battle to make the 19th Amendment a reality.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Chambers, Jennifer Schuessler, Amisha Padnani, Jennifer Harlan, Sandra E. Garcia and Vivian Wang
item.category: Finish the Fight!: The Brave and Revolutionary Women Who Fought for the Right to Vote (Book)

item.title: 73,400 New Coronavirus Cases in U.S., Nearing Single-Day Record
item.description: South Korea reported its biggest jump in new cases since March. Nancy Pelosi, pushing for a broader aid package, rejected a short extension of relief benefits.

item.title: A Climate Plan in Texas Focuses on Minorities. Not Everyone Likes It.
item.description: For years, money for flood protection in the Houston area went mostly to richer neighborhoods. A new approach prioritizes minority communities, and it’s stirring up resentments.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Sergio Flores for The New York Times
item.media:description: Faith and Skye Palay of Houston are forbidden to play in their front yard, where water pools and mosquitos breed. Their mother advocates for flood protection in minority areas.

item.title: Routine Beatings of Inmates in Alabama Prisons Go Ignored, U.S. Says
item.description: A report released by the Justice Department found that corrections officers frequently used excessive force and violated prisoners’ constitutional rights.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Corrections officers at Alabama prisons frequently use excessive force, a report by the Justice Department said.

item.title: The Doctor From Nazi Germany and the Search for Life on Mars
item.description: Astrobiologists have used Mars jars for decades. Many didn’t know about the controversial Air Force scientist who started them.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Scoles
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The Star of This $70 Million Sci-Fi Film Is a Robot
item.description: Meet Erica, an android believed to be Hollywood’s first fully autonomous artificially intelligent actor. Can she overcome the uncanny valley?
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:description: The producer Sam Khoze with Erica, the android star of the film “b.”

item.title: How to Dress for the Protest
item.description: “On a daily basis I think about what I’m wearing.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Passmore
